protocol.label: The Science Behind the Simplicity
protocol.title: The Protocol
protocol.subtitle: How we hack ADHD brains into getting shit done

problem.title: The Problem
problem.p1: Most productivity apps fail ADHD brains because they demand management before action.
problem.highlight: The ADHD problem isn't "not knowing what to do." It's breaking through the Wall of Awful to start.

pavlov.title: PAVLOV YOURSELF
pavlov.subtitle: Neuro-Anchoring
pavlov.quote: You sit on the couch and watch movies. Your brain now associates that couch with movies. You scroll TikTok in bed at night, your brain now associates your bed with TikTok.
pavlov.p1: We are highly adaptive creatures. The more you repeat, the more you associate. Use this to your benefit.
pavlov.principle1: Dedicate a specific playlist ONLY for deep work
pavlov.principle2: Dedicate a specific environment ONLY for focus
pavlov.principle3: Dedicate a specific ritual ONLY for execution
pavlov.warning: You break the association bond the second you start watching YouTube on your work computer or listen to your work playlist while doing something else. Conditioning requires absolute consistency.
pavlov.how1: Integrated playlist with scientific tracks (binaural beats, isochronic tones)
pavlov.how2: Sound that is monotonous in a good way - occupies the part of your brain looking for distraction without engaging linguistic processing
pavlov.how3: User hears the sound - brain thinks: "Focus time." Daily repetition strengthens the neural trigger.

clutter.title: REMOVE MENTAL CLUTTER
clutter.subtitle: Zero Friction
clutter.quote: We are non-linear thinkers. One idea sparks another which sparks another.
clutter.p1: Every decision is cognitive cost. Every option is an opportunity to procrastinate.
clutter.principle2: Every element on screen must justify its existence
clutter.principle3: If it doesn't help execution, it hurts it
clutter.how1: not developer laziness, it's cognitive accessibility
clutter.how4: text + checkbox. No tags, no colors, no priorities
clutter.math:
Friction = Decisions x Time per Decision x Cognitive Energy

Login = +1 decision (which email?)
Tags = +N decisions (which tag? which color?)
Settings = +N decisions (how long? which sound? which theme?)

More decisions = Less energy for real work
clutter.mathConclusion: Every feature removed is value added.

distractions.title: MAKE DISTRACTIONS IMPOSSIBLE
distractions.subtitle: Active Defense
distractions.quote: You will inevitably reach for distractions. You'll convince yourself you're thirsty, need to go to the bathroom, or have to check email. You don't.
distractions.p1: The ADHD brain is a dopamine predator. Any pause in activity is an opening for distraction.
distractions.principle2: Keep the work pace high - any lull causes focus loss
distractions.principle3: Every time you catch yourself distracted and reorient, you get better at focusing
distractions.how2: shows remaining time even in other tabs
distractions.blindness1: People with ADHD suffer from time blindness. 15 minutes and 3 hours feel the same in our heads.
distractions.blindness2: The visible timer solves this. Time stops being an abstract feeling and becomes a concrete number counting down. This creates real urgency, not artificial.

timebatch.title: TIME BATCH
timebatch.subtitle: Race the Clock
timebatch.quote: Something you think will take an hour ends up taking 15 minutes and vice versa.
timebatch.p1: ADHD brains work great under pressure but have horrible temporal awareness. So don't batch work by task - batch by time.
timebatch.principle1: Set a timer for 25 minutes and an objective
timebatch.principle2: Race to get it done before the clock runs out
timebatch.principle3: The pressure creates focus that willpower alone can't
timebatch.how1: no negotiating with yourself about "just 5 more minutes"
timebatch.how2: creates urgency and competitive pressure against yourself
timebatch.how3: one clear objective per time block
timebatch.closing: I love pressure and competition. Racing against the clock gives me no other option but to dial in.

prepare.title: DON'T START, PREPARE
prepare.subtitle: Negotiate with Your Brain
prepare.quote: The ADHD brain cannot be brute-forced into doing work. It must be negotiated with.
prepare.p1: No matter how hard you try, you can't start a new task. That's okay. Instead, start preparing everything you need to do that task at a later date.
prepare.principle3: Preparation often turns into execution naturally
prepare.how1: write down what you'll work on - that's preparation
prepare.how2: no searching for the right playlist
prepare.how3: everything is prepared, just hit play
prepare.closing: The trick: Once you start preparing, your brain often slips into actually doing the work. Preparation is the backdoor to execution.

pressure.title: EMBRACE PRESSURE & CONSTRAINTS
pressure.subtitle: Pressure Creates Diamonds
pressure.quote: The ADHD brain is constantly understimulated. One of the best ways to stimulate it is to add pressure.
pressure.p1: I perform best when I have a full plate. It forces you to focus on the 20% of tasks that yield 80% of results. There's not much motivation to hunt when you only have one mouth to feed.
pressure.principle3: Constantly try to get more done in less time
pressure.how1: 25 minutes forces you to prioritize what actually matters
pressure.how2: the clock keeps ticking - embrace the pressure
pressure.closing: One of the many paradoxes of the neurodivergent brain: we need more pressure, not less.
